description: Borrowed from Latin sonorus, from sonor (“sound”), early 17th century.

adjectives.description: sonorous (comparative more sonorous, superlative most sonorous)

entries.meaning: Capable of giving out a deep, resonant sound.
examples: The highlight of the hike was the sonorous cave, which produced a ringing echo from the hiker’s shouts.

entries.meaning: Full of sound and rich, as in language or verse.
examples: He was selected to give the opening speech thanks to his imposing, sonorous voice.

entries.meaning: (linguistics, phonetics) Produced with a relatively open vocal tract and relatively little obstruction of airflow.
